comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,176 @@ +--- +title: Image +--- + +Images can enrich web content, but they can also introduce performance issues, from reducing a page’s time to [Largest Contentful Paint](https://web.dev/lcp/) to introducing [Cumulative Layout Shift](https://web.dev/cls/). + +The Enhance image component is designed to help alleviate these issues for images stored in your project’s [public folder](/docs/learn/starter-project/public), by providing: + +
+
Configurable image optimization
+
Generate alternative formats, set quality levels for lossy formats, and generate different image sizes on the fly.
+ +
Responsive images
+
The picture element offers a lot of power in delivering images tailored to different media conditions, but it can be challenging to implement correctly. The image component abstracts and simplifies this API to make responsive images a breeze.
+ +
Generated sizing attributes
+
For each image variant you provide, the image component will generate corresponding width and height attributes to prevent layout shift from occurring.
+ +
Lazy loading
+
Images that aren’t critical for a page’s initial render can be lazy loaded to improve the critical rendering path.
+
+ +## Usage + +### enhance-image +This parent element is used to specify your image’s source, its loading strategy, and any alt text you wish to provide. + +#### Attributes + +
+
src required
+
The path to your source image. In order to take advantage of image optimization, your image must reside in your project’s public folder. This source will also be used as the fallback image in case none of the provided enhance-image-variants’ media conditions are matched by the client.
+ +
alt
+
Alternative text description of the image. Read more about the alt attribute here.
+ +
loading
+
The loading strategy to be used. Can be either eager to load the image immediately, or lazy to defer loading until the image approaches the viewport. Defaults to eager. Read more about the loading attribute here.
+
+ +### enhance-image-variant +This element is used to specify a variation of your source image. This is where you can apply image optimization to your source image, as well as specific media conditions under which the variant should be rendered. + +#### Attributes + +
+
format
+
The desired format for the generated image. Available formats are jpg, png, gif, webp, and avif. Defaults to the source image format. + + + Not all browsers support all image formats — see [MDN’s image filetype and format guide](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Formats/Image_types) for reference. + +
+ +
media
+
The media condition under which the generated image should be displayed. If a media condition is not provided, the image will be rendered under all media conditions, unless a variant with a matching media condition precedes it. + + + Due to [the design of the underlying specification](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#selecting-an-image-source), the order of media conditions is important: unlike in CSS, the browser will use the _first_ matching media condition it encounters, rather than examining each media condition for the best fit. + + + + + + As a safety net, where media conditions are all of type `min-width` or `max-width`, these will be reordered into the expected sequence by the component (descending for `min-width`, ascending for `max-width`). The authored order will persist in the generated output if other media features (or multiple media features) are used. + +
+ +
quality
+
The quality setting controls the amount of compression to apply to the generated image. Acceptsa numeric string from 0 to 100. Higher numbers result in higher quality and less compression, at the expense of larger file size. Defaults to full quality. TODO: which formats is this available for?
comment.body: Should be `Accepts a` not `Acceptsa`

issue.title: Make it easier to get your access token from the CLI

```bash
begin builds 3M6TLM6N
begin builds 3M6TLM6N --env B8J14RLR9

Instead of:

begin builds --app 3M6TLM6N
begin builds --app 3M6TLM6N --env B8J14RLR9
```

pull_request.title: adding quote context to AST
pull_request.body: This PR changes parsing/compilation to better support escape quoted strings. The native arc file format supports backtick, single, and double quotes. Compiling to JS should be lossy (the quotes are gone) which was the original behavior. Compiling to arc should not be lossy so parsing/changing a native arc file can retain userland choices about escaping.

issue.title: Include user interaction example
issue.body:
Love the clean back-to-basics syntax of Enhance! Great work!

One thing that I feel is missing from the docs is how to implement interactivity, since the developer ergonomics of binding syntax is one of the key differentiators in other frameworks.

It could be as complex as a full TodoMVC app or as simple as a "click a button to update some state" example. I wanted to recreate the 'CounterButton' example from this blog post: https://joshcollinsworth.com/blog/introducing-svelte-comparing-with-react-vue#authoring-svelte-components, but ended up having to use the `enhance('counter-button', { ... })` syntax, which felt like a step back into non-standard module land.

I understand that Enhance is meant to enhance vanilla JavaScript, and as such it may not offer any syntactic sugar for value binding, but even so, it would be helpful to include a best-practice example of how it should be done.

comment.body:
@JensRoland did you mean the code is a bit terse? How can it be improved to be more explicit? 

I'm re-opening the issue so we can add more docs around this topic.

issue.title: Deploy strips quotes in arc file
issue.body:
If you have quotes in the arc file:
```
@bundles
store 'node_modules/@enhance/store'
parser 'node_modules/@architect/parser'
```
and you deploy the CLI will strip the quotes off and the arc file will fail because of the @ symbol inside the string.

pull_request.title: Quoted strings in arrays
pull_request.body:
When we need to quote a string in an array value like:

```
@bundles
store 'node_modules/@enhance/store'
```

The compiler will output a string that no longer contains the single quotes (or double quotes). Then when you attempt to parse the arc file it will fail due to the `@` character.

Related issue https://github.com/beginner-corp/cli/issues/72

pull_request.title: Add session to store
pull_request.body:
This three line change adds the `req.session` into the store. This is super useful for components that depend on data from the session. The main use case is authentication. I don't want to have to create an API route for every page that needs my account information so the API can read the session and add it to the store. This change makes it automatic. So a login button could look like: ```javascript export default function BeginLogin({ html, state }) { const { store } = state const { session } = store const { account } = session return html`
  • ${ account ? `Log Out` : `Log In`}
    • ` } ``` Signed-off-by: macdonst

pull_request.title: PROPOSAL: Enhance image component
pull_request.body:
This PR proposes documentation for the forthcoming Enhance image component. The implementation of the component will be informed by these docs, so let's be sure to examine every aspect mentioned in the docs closely, and tease out anything that's missing or unclear. If anything about the proposal feels off, now is the ideal time to discuss!

## Other changes
Made a couple minor typography changes for `code` (to get x-height closer to the body typeface) and `code`'s background colour within `doc-callout`s.

## To Do
- [ ] Determine which image formats the `quality` setting can be applied to
- [ ] Verify we can extract the source image's width and height and set this on the generated `img` element

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,176 @@ +--- +title: Image +--- + +Images can enrich web content, but they can also introduce performance issues, from reducing a page’s time to [Largest Contentful Paint](https://web.dev/lcp/) to introducing [Cumulative Layout Shift](https://web.dev/cls/). + +The Enhance image component is designed to help alleviate these issues for images stored in your project’s [public folder](/docs/learn/starter-project/public), by providing: + +
+
Configurable image optimization
+
Generate alternative formats, set quality levels for lossy formats, and generate different image sizes on the fly.
+ +
Responsive images
+
The picture element offers a lot of power in delivering images tailored to different media conditions, but it can be challenging to implement correctly. The image component abstracts and simplifies this API to make responsive images a breeze.
+ +
Generated sizing attributes
+
For each image variant you provide, the image component will generate corresponding width and height attributes to prevent layout shift from occurring.
+ +
Lazy loading
+
Images that aren’t critical for a page’s initial render can be lazy loaded to improve the critical rendering path.
+
+ +## Usage + +### enhance-image +This parent element is used to specify your image’s source, its loading strategy, and any alt text you wish to provide. + +#### Attributes + +
+
src required
+
The path to your source image. In order to take advantage of image optimization, your image must reside in your project’s public folder. This source will also be used as the fallback image in case none of the provided enhance-image-variants’ media conditions are matched by the client.
+ +
alt
+
Alternative text description of the image. Read more about the alt attribute here.
+ +
loading
+
The loading strategy to be used. Can be either eager to load the image immediately, or lazy to defer loading until the image approaches the viewport. Defaults to eager. Read more about the loading attribute here.
+
+ +### enhance-image-variant +This element is used to specify a variation of your source image. This is where you can apply image optimization to your source image, as well as specific media conditions under which the variant should be rendered. + +#### Attributes + +
+
format
+
The desired format for the generated image. Available formats are jpg, png, gif, webp, and avif. Defaults to the source image format. + + + Not all browsers support all image formats — see [MDN’s image filetype and format guide](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Formats/Image_types) for reference. + +
+ +
media
+
The media condition under which the generated image should be displayed. If a media condition is not provided, the image will be rendered under all media conditions, unless a variant with a matching media condition precedes it. + + + Due to [the design of the underlying specification](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#selecting-an-image-source), the order of media conditions is important: unlike in CSS, the browser will use the _first_ matching media condition it encounters, rather than examining each media condition for the best fit. + + + + + + As a safety net, where media conditions are all of type `min-width` or `max-width`, these will be reordered into the expected sequence by the component (descending for `min-width`, ascending for `max-width`). The authored order will persist in the generated output if other media features (or multiple media features) are used. + +
+ +
quality
+
The quality setting controls the amount of compression to apply to the generated image. Acceptsa numeric string from 0 to 100. Higher numbers result in higher quality and less compression, at the expense of larger file size. Defaults to full quality. TODO: which formats is this available for?
comment.body: Should be `Accepts a` not `Acceptsa`

issue.title: Queue up a deploy if one is in process
issue.body: If we have two commits to a repo that trigger a `begin deploy` the first one wins and the second one never runs. It would be great if the `deploy.sh` command went to sleep and retried the deploy if it detects an ongoing deploy.

issue.title: Make it easier to get your access token from the CLI
issue.body: You need to set your begin access token in GitHub secrets to be able to deploy via an action. It would be great if `begin login` would copy your access token to the clipboard or `begin login --json` would include it as part of it's output.

pull_request.title: App ID is required for builds
pull_request.body:
Switching the optional setting to environment since `begin builds` requires an app ID.

Follow up question, since the app ID is required should the command be:

```bash
begin builds 3M6TLM6N
begin builds 3M6TLM6N --env B8J14RLR9
```

Instead of:

```bash
begin builds --app 3M6TLM6N
begin builds --app 3M6TLM6N --env B8J14RLR9
```

pull_request.title: adding quote context to AST
pull_request.body: This PR changes parsing/compilation to better support escape quoted strings. The native arc file format supports backtick, single, and double quotes. Compiling to JS should be lossy (the quotes are gone) which was the original behavior. Compiling to arc should not be lossy so parsing/changing a native arc file can retain userland choices about escaping.

issue.title: Include user interaction example
issue.body:
Love the clean back-to-basics syntax of Enhance! Great work!

One thing that I feel is missing from the docs is how to implement interactivity, since the developer ergonomics of binding syntax is one of the key differentiators in other frameworks.

It could be as complex as a full TodoMVC app or as simple as a "click a button to update some state" example. I wanted to recreate the 'CounterButton' example from this blog post: https://joshcollinsworth.com/blog/introducing-svelte-comparing-with-react-vue#authoring-svelte-components, but ended up having to use the `enhance('counter-button', { ... })` syntax, which felt like a step back into non-standard module land.

I understand that Enhance is meant to enhance vanilla JavaScript, and as such it may not offer any syntactic sugar for value binding, but even so, it would be helpful to include a best-practice example of how it should be done.

comment.body:
@JensRoland did you mean the code is a bit terse? How can it be improved to be more explicit? 

I'm re-opening the issue so we can add more docs around this topic.

issue.title: Deploy strips quotes in arc file
issue.body:
If you have quotes in the arc file:
```
@bundles
store 'node_modules/@enhance/store'
parser 'node_modules/@architect/parser'
```
and you deploy the CLI will strip the quotes off and the arc file will fail because of the @ symbol inside the string.

pull_request.title: Quoted strings in arrays
pull_request.body:
When we need to quote a string in an array value like:

```
@bundles
store 'node_modules/@enhance/store'
```

The compiler will output a string that no longer contains the single quotes (or double quotes). Then when you attempt to parse the arc file it will fail due to the `@` character.

Related issue https://github.com/beginner-corp/cli/issues/72

pull_request.title: Add session to store
pull_request.body:
This three line change adds the `req.session` into the store. This is super useful for components that depend on data from the session. The main use case is authentication. I don't want to have to create an API route for every page that needs my account information so the API can read the session and add it to the store. This change makes it automatic. So a login button could look like: ```javascript export default function BeginLogin({ html, state }) { const { store } = state const { session } = store const { account } = session return html`
  • ${ account ? `Log Out` : `Log In`}
    • ` } ``` Signed-off-by: macdonst

pull_request.title: PROPOSAL: Enhance image component
pull_request.body:
This PR proposes documentation for the forthcoming Enhance image component. The implementation of the component will be informed by these docs, so let's be sure to examine every aspect mentioned in the docs closely, and tease out anything that's missing or unclear. If anything about the proposal feels off, now is the ideal time to discuss!

## Other changes
Made a couple minor typography changes for `code` (to get x-height closer to the body typeface) and `code`'s background colour within `doc-callout`s.

## To Do
- [ ] Determine which image formats the `quality` setting can be applied to
- [ ] Verify we can extract the source image's width and height and set this on the generated `img` element

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,176 @@ +--- +title: Image +--- + +Images can enrich web content, but they can also introduce performance issues, from reducing a page’s time to [Largest Contentful Paint](https://web.dev/lcp/) to introducing [Cumulative Layout Shift](https://web.dev/cls/). + +The Enhance image component is designed to help alleviate these issues for images stored in your project’s [public folder](/docs/learn/starter-project/public), by providing: + +
+
Configurable image optimization
+
Generate alternative formats, set quality levels for lossy formats, and generate different image sizes on the fly.
+ +
Responsive images
+
The picture element offers a lot of power in delivering images tailored to different media conditions, but it can be challenging to implement correctly. The image component abstracts and simplifies this API to make responsive images a breeze.
+ +
Generated sizing attributes
+
For each image variant you provide, the image component will generate corresponding width and height attributes to prevent layout shift from occurring.
+ +
Lazy loading
+
Images that aren’t critical for a page’s initial render can be lazy loaded to improve the critical rendering path.
+
+ +## Usage + +### enhance-image +This parent element is used to specify your image’s source, its loading strategy, and any alt text you wish to provide. + +#### Attributes + +
+
src required
+
The path to your source image. In order to take advantage of image optimization, your image must reside in your project’s public folder. This source will also be used as the fallback image in case none of the provided enhance-image-variants’ media conditions are matched by the client.
+ +
alt
+
Alternative text description of the image. Read more about the alt attribute here.
+ +
loading
+
The loading strategy to be used. Can be either eager to load the image immediately, or lazy to defer loading until the image approaches the viewport. Defaults to eager. Read more about the loading attribute here.
+
+ +### enhance-image-variant +This element is used to specify a variation of your source image. This is where you can apply image optimization to your source image, as well as specific media conditions under which the variant should be rendered. + +#### Attributes + +
+
format
+
The desired format for the generated image. Available formats are jpg, png, gif, webp, and avif. Defaults to the source image format. + + + Not all browsers support all image formats — see [MDN’s image filetype and format guide](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Media/Formats/Image_types) for reference. + +
+ +
media
+
The media condition under which the generated image should be displayed. If a media condition is not provided, the image will be rendered under all media conditions, unless a variant with a matching media condition precedes it. + + + Due to [the design of the underlying specification](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#selecting-an-image-source), the order of media conditions is important: unlike in CSS, the browser will use the _first_ matching media condition it encounters, rather than examining each media condition for the best fit. + + + + + + As a safety net, where media conditions are all of type `min-width` or `max-width`, these will be reordered into the expected sequence by the component (descending for `min-width`, ascending for `max-width`). The authored order will persist in the generated output if other media features (or multiple media features) are used. + +
+ +
quality
+
The quality setting controls the amount of compression to apply to the generated image. Acceptsa numeric string from 0 to 100. Higher numbers result in higher quality and less compression, at the expense of larger file size. Defaults to full quality. TODO: which formats is this available for?
comment.body: Should be `Accepts a` not `Acceptsa`

issue.title: Queue up a deploy if one is in process
issue.body: If we have two commits to a repo that trigger a `begin deploy` the first one wins and the second one never runs. It would be great if the `deploy.sh` command went to sleep and retried the deploy if it detects an ongoing deploy.

issue.title: Make it easier to get your access token from the CLI
issue.body: You need to set your begin access token in GitHub secrets to be able to deploy via an action. It would be great if `begin login` would copy your access token to the clipboard or `begin login --json` would include it as part of it's output.

pull_request.title: App ID is required for builds
pull_request.body:
Switching the optional setting to environment since `begin builds` requires an app ID.

Follow up question, since the app ID is required should the command be:

```bash
begin builds 3M6TLM6N
begin builds 3M6TLM6N --env B8J14RLR9
```

Instead of:

```bash
begin builds --app 3M6TLM6N
begin builds --app 3M6TLM6N --env B8J14RLR9
```

review.body: We need to revert the changes in `src/compiler/arc.js` and `src/compiler/yaml.js` as well.

pull_request.title: adding quote context to AST
pull_request.body: This PR changes parsing/compilation to better support escape quoted strings. The native arc file format supports backtick, single, and double quotes. Compiling to JS should be lossy (the quotes are gone) which was the original behavior. Compiling to arc should not be lossy so parsing/changing a native arc file can retain userland choices about escaping.

issue.title: Include user interaction example
issue.body:
Love the clean back-to-basics syntax of Enhance! Great work!

One thing that I feel is missing from the docs is how to implement interactivity, since the developer ergonomics of binding syntax is one of the key differentiators in other frameworks.

It could be as complex as a full TodoMVC app or as simple as a "click a button to update some state" example. I wanted to recreate the 'CounterButton' example from this blog post: https://joshcollinsworth.com/blog/introducing-svelte-comparing-with-react-vue#authoring-svelte-components, but ended up having to use the `enhance('counter-button', { ... })` syntax, which felt like a step back into non-standard module land.

I understand that Enhance is meant to enhance vanilla JavaScript, and as such it may not offer any syntactic sugar for value binding, but even so, it would be helpful to include a best-practice example of how it should be done.

comment.body:
@JensRoland did you mean the code is a bit terse? How can it be improved to be more explicit? 

I'm re-opening the issue so we can add more docs around this topic.

issue.title: Deploy strips quotes in arc file
issue.body:
If you have quotes in the arc file:
```
@bundles
store 'node_modules/@enhance/store'
parser 'node_modules/@architect/parser'
```
and you deploy the CLI will strip the quotes off and the arc file will fail because of the @ symbol inside the string.

pull_request.title: Quoted strings in arrays
pull_request.body:
When we need to quote a string in an array value like:

```
@bundles
store 'node_modules/@enhance/store'
```

The compiler will output a string that no longer contains the single quotes (or double quotes). Then when you attempt to parse the arc file it will fail due to the `@` character.

Related issue https://github.com/beginner-corp/cli/issues/72

pull_request.title: Add session to store
pull_request.body:
This three line change adds the `req.session` into the store. This is super useful for components that depend on data from the session. The main use case is authentication. I don't want to have to create an API route for every page that needs my account information so the API can read the session and add it to the store. This change makes it automatic. So a login button could look like: ```javascript export default function BeginLogin({ html, state }) { const { store } = state const { session } = store const { account } = session return html`
  • ${ account ? `Log Out` : `Log In`}
    • ` } ``` Signed-off-by: macdonst
